answers.author: Thomas Wieczorek
answers.text:
The traditional sirens are normally thought to be effective in rural areas but can have limited effectiveness in built up urban centers.  There are firms that will assist in locating the sirens to provide a full range of coverage. 
An integrated approach is the best method for alerting residents, particularly during evening or early morning hours. IPAWS (http://www.fema.gov/integrated-public-alert-warning-system)
has proven quite successful in alerting residents.
Paying for the costs of acquiring and installing sirens can come from local funds or FEMA mitigation grants. Whenever a presidential disaster is declared, a portion of money is set aside under the Robert T. Stafford Act for mitigation efforts which prevent loss of life or property damage in future events. Having prepared plans for replacement or purchase of items like the siren alerting system is critical towards getting funding as future efforts will center around pre-approved THIRA plans (Threat, Hazard Identification and Risk Assessment).

author: David Robinson
text: Has anyone had any experience working with the 'air raid' type of sirens used to (predominantly) notify residents about impending weather events or utility problems?  Are there locations where they are required by law or statute?  Are there any anecdotes about switching to other forms of communication that are more cost-beneficial?  Any information is appreciated.
title: Emergency alert sirens - mandates?  experiences? alternatives?
